with quote from [[Tess Gerritsen]] | author = [[Paula Hawkins (author)|Paula Hawkins]] | audio_read_by = {{Plainlist| * [[Clare Corbett]] * [[Louise Brealey]] * [[India Fisher]] }} | country = United Kingdom | language = English | genre = | published = 13 January 2015 ([[Riverhead Books]], US)
15 January 2015 ([[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]], UK) | media_type = Print (hardback) | pages = 395 (US)
320 (UK) | isbn = 978-1-59463-366-9 | congress = }} '''''The Girl on the Train''''' (2015) is a [[thriller (genre)|psychological thriller]] novel by [[British literature|British author]] [[Paula Hawkins (author)|Paula Hawkins]].{{cite news |date=4 January 2015 |first=Janet |last=Maslin |authorlink=Janet Maslin |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/05/books/the-girl-on-the-train-by-paula-hawkins.html |title=Another Girl Gone in a Tale of Betrayal – 'The Girl on the Train' by Paula Hawkins |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=1 July 2016}} The novel debuted at No. 1 on [[The New York Times Fiction Best Sellers of 2015|''The New York Times'' Fiction Best Sellers of 2015]] list (combined print and [[e-book]]) dated 1 February 2015,{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2015-02-01/combined-print-and-e-book-fiction/list.html |title=Best Sellers: Combined Print & E-Book Fiction |newspaper=The New York Times |date=1 February 2015 |accessdate=1 July 2016}} and remained in the top position for 13 consecutive weeks, until April 2015.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2015-04-26/hardcover-fiction/list.html |title=Best Sellers : Hardcover Fiction |newspaper=The New York Times |date=26 April 2015 |accessdate=1 July 2016}} In January 2016 it became the No.1 best-seller again for two weeks. Many reviews referred to the book as "the next ''[[Gone Girl (novel)|Gone Girl]]''", referring to a popular 2012 psychological mystery with similar themes and use of [[unreliable narrator]]s.{{Cite web |url=http://paulahawkinsbooks.com/the-girl-on-the-train-by-paula-hawkins/ |title=Review excerpts |website=paulahawkinsbooks.com |accessdate=21 April 2015}}{{cite news |last=Lawless |first=Jill |date=22 March 2015 |url=http://www.redding.com/lifestyle/the-girl-on-the-train-is-a-runaway-hit-for-paula-hawkins |title='The Girl on the Train' is a runaway hit for Paula Hawkins |newspaper=[[Redding Record Searchlight]] |agency=[[Associated Press]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150325080551/http://www.redding.com/lifestyle/the-girl-on-the-train-is-a-runaway-hit-for-paula-hawkins |archivedate=25 March 2015}} By early March 2015, the novel had sold over 1 million copies,{{Cite news |last=McClurg |first=Jocelyn |date=11 March 2015 |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/books/2015/03/11/the-girl-on-the-train-paula-hawkins-1-million-copies/70144814/ |title='Girl on the Train' sells 1 million copies |newspaper=[[USA Today]]}} and 1.5 million by April.{{Cite web |last=O'Connor |first=William |date=20 April 2015 |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2015/04/20/the-fastest-selling-adult-novel-in-history-paula-hawkins-the-girl-on-the-train.html |title=The Fastest-Selling Adult Novel in History: Paula Hawkins' 'The Girl On The Train' |website=[[The Daily Beast]]}} It has occupied the number one spot of the UK hardback book chart for 20 weeks, the longest any book has ever held the top spot.{{Cite news |first=Alison |last=Flood |url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2015/jul/08/the-girl-on-the-train-book-sales-record-paula-hawkins |title=The Girl on the Train breaks all-time book sales record |newspaper=The Guardian |date=8 July 2015}} By early August 2015, the book had sold more than 3 million copies in the US alone, and, by October 2016, an estimated 15 million copies worldwide.{{cite news |newspaper=The Wall Street Journal |first=Lucy |last=Feldman |date=10 October 2016 |url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2016/10/10/what-paula-hawkins-thinks-of-the-girl-on-the-train-movie/ |title=What Paula Hawkins Thinks of 'The Girl on the Train' Movie |quote='Of course I was nervous,' says Paula Hawkins, author of 'The Girl on the Train', which has sold more than 20 million copies around the world.'}} The audiobook edition, narrated by [[Clare Corbett]], [[Louise Brealey]] and [[India Fisher]] (released by [[Books on Tape (company)|Books on Tape]]) won the 2016 [[Audie Award]] for Audiobook of the Year.{{Cite web |url=http://www.booksontape.com/paula-hawkins-the-girl-on-the-train-exclusive-audio-clips/ |title=Meet the Cast: The girls from Paula Hawkins' "The Girl On The Train" (Exclusive Audio Clips) |website=Books on Tape |access-date=1 January 2017}}{{Cite web |url=http://www.booklistreader.com/2016/05/11/audiobooks/the-years-best-audiobooks-2016-audie-award-winners/ |title=The Year's Best Audiobooks: 2016 Audie Award Winners |date=11 May 2016 |website=The Booklist Reader |access-date=1 January 2017}} The film rights were acquired by [[DreamWorks|DreamWorks Pictures]] in 2014 for Marc Platt Productions.{{Cite magazine |title=DreamWorks Acquires Novel 'The Girl on the Train' for Marc Platt |url=https://variety.com/2014/film/news/dreamworks-the-girl-on-the-train-for-marc-platt-1201144671/ |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |date=24 March 2014 |accessdate=29 June 2016 |first=Justin |last=Kroll}} The [[The Girl on the Train (2016 film)|film adaptation]], starring [[Emily Blunt]] and directed by [[Tate Taylor]], was released on 7 October 2016. ==Plot== The story is a [[first-person narrative]] told from the point of view of three women: Rachel, Anna, and Megan. Rachel Watson is a 32-year-old alcoholic, reeling from the end of her marriage to Tom, who left her for another woman, Anna Watson. Rachel's drinking has caused her to lose her job; she frequently binges and has [[Blackout (drug-related amnesia)|blackouts]]. While drunk, she often harasses Tom, though she has little or no memory of these acts once she sobers up. Tom is now married to Anna and has a daughter with her, Evie – a situation that fuels Rachel's self-destructive tendencies, as it was her inability to conceive a child that began her spiral into alcoholism. Rachel follows her old routine of taking the train to London everyday; her train slowly passes her old house, where Tom, Anna, and Evie now live. She also begins watching from the train an attractive couple who live a few houses away from Tom. She idealises their life (christening them "Jason" and "Jess"), though she has no idea that their life is far from perfect. The wife of the couple, Megan Hipwell ("Jess"), has a troubled past. She finds her life boring, and escapes from her troubles by taking a series of lovers. Megan has sought help by seeing a therapist, Dr. Kamal Abdic. Eventually, she reveals to him a dark secret she has never confided to anyone before. Anna is young, beautiful, in love with Tom, and happy as a stay-at-home mother to the young Evie. While at first she enjoyed the idea of showing off to Rachel that Tom picked her over Rachel, she eventually becomes furious at Rachel's harassment of her family. One day, Rachel is stunned to see Megan kissing another man. The next day, after heavy drinking, Rachel awakens to find herself bloody and injured, with no memories of the night before. She learns that Megan is missing, and is questioned by the police after Anna reports having seen her drunkenly staggering around the night of Megan's disappearance. Rachel becomes interested in the case and tells the police she thinks Megan was having an affair. She then contacts Megan's husband, Scott ("Jason") and tells him as well, lying that she and Megan were friends. Rachel learns that the man she saw kissing Megan was Kamal. Rachel contacts Kamal, lying about her identity to get close to him and learn more about him. She makes a therapy appointment with him to see if he can help her recall the events that happened during her blackout that night. While Kamal suspects nothing, Rachel begins to gain insight into her life by speaking with him, inadvertently benefiting from the therapy. Her connections to Scott and Kamal, though built on lies, make her feel more important. She ends up not drinking for several days at a time but always relapses. Meanwhile, she continues to call, visit, and harass Tom. Megan's body is found; she is revealed to have been pregnant, and her unborn child was fathered by neither Scott nor Kamal. As Scott discovers Rachel's lies and lashes out at her, her memories become clearer. Rachel remembers seeing Megan get into Tom's car. Anna discovers that Tom and Megan were having an affair. Rachel begins trusting her own memories more, and realises that many of the crazy things Tom told her she did while drunk never really happened. He had been [[gaslighting]] her for years, which made her question her sanity. Armed with this sad realisation, and the knowledge that he must have been the one who killed Megan, Rachel warns Anna. When Anna confronts him, Tom confesses to murdering Megan after she threatened to reveal that he had gotten her pregnant. Anna is cowed, fearing for her daughter's safety. Tom tries to beat and intimidate Rachel into keeping silent but she defies him and fights back. Knowing he is about to kill her, Rachel stabs Tom in the neck with a corkscrew. Anna helps Rachel make sure that he dies from the wound. When the police arrive, former adversaries Rachel and Anna support each other by co-ordinating their stories to explain their actions as self-defence. Finally free, Rachel decides to quit drinking and move on with her life. ==Reception== ''The Girl on the Train'' received mostly positive reviews from critics and audiences alike. In 2015 it became the fastest-selling adult hardcover novel in history, and it spent over four months on the ''New York Times'' Bestseller List following its release. ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' praised the novel with a starred review, writing that "even the most astute readers will be in for a shock as Hawkins slowly unspools the facts, exposing the harsh realities of love and obsession's inescapable links to violence." Subsequently, the novel was honoured by ''Kirkus Reviews'' as one of the best books of 2015, in the fiction category. The book also won the 2015 [[Goodreads]] Choice Award in the category Mystery & Thriller.{{cite web |url=http://www.goodreads.com/choiceawards/best-books-2015 |title=The 2015 Goodreads Choice Awards |website=Goodreads.com}} In a less positive review for ''[[The New York Times]]'', Jean Hanff Korelitz questioned the novel's narrative structure and criticised the protagonist for behaving "illogically, self-destructively, and narcissistically."{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2015/02/01/books/review/the-girl-on-the-train-by-paula-hawkins.html |title='The Girl on the Train' by Paula Hawkins |first=Jean Hanff |last=Korelitz |date=30 January 2015 |newspaper=The New York Times}} ''The Girl on the Train'' has been compared frequently to ''[[Gone Girl (novel)|Gone Girl]]'' by [[Gillian Flynn]], as both novels employ unreliable narrators and deal with suburban life. Paula Hawkins has waved these comparisons off, however, saying in an interview with ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'': "Amy Dunne is a [[psychopath]], an incredibly controlling and manipulative, smart, cunning woman. [Rachel is] just a mess who can't do anything right."{{cite magazine |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/girl-train-author-shoots-down-932781 |title='Girl on the Train' Author Shoots Down 'Gone Girl' Comparisons |date=28 September 2016 |first=Tatiana |last=Siegel |magazine=The Hollywood Reporter}} ==Translations== The foreign rights have been sold in 34 countries, and the book has been translated into many languages, including: {| class="wikitable" !Language !Publisher !Book name !Translator |- |Arabic{{cite web |url=http://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1623881228 |title=Humood's review of فتاة القطار |website=www.goodreads.com |language=ar |accessdate=16 April 2018}} |منشورات الرمل Manshurat Al-Raml | فتاة القطار
''Fatāh al-Qiṭār'' |Al Harith Al Nabhan (الحارث النبهان) |- |Bulgarian{{cite web |url=http://enthusiast.bg/bg/book/296 |title=Момичето от влака, Паула Хоукинс |website=enthusiast.bg |language=bg|accessdate=16 April 2018}} |Enthusiast |Момичето от влака |Margarita Terzieva (Маргарита Терзиева) |- |French{{cite web |url=http://www.sonatine-editions.fr/livres/La-Fille-du-train.asp |title=La Fille du train |website=Sonatine Editions |language=fr |accessdate=16 April 2018}} |Sonatine Éditions |''La Fille du train'' |Corinne Daniellot |- |[[Danish language|Danish]]{{cite web |url=http://www.gyldendal.dk/produkter/paula-hawkins/kvinden-i-toget-39662/paperback-9788702217872 |title=Kvinden i toget |website=[[Gyldendal]] |language=da |accessdate=16 April 2018}} |Gyldendal |''Kvinden i toget'' |Steffen Rayburn-Maarup |- |Persian{{cite web |url=https://www.digikala.com/Product/DKP-104200/%DA%A9%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A8-%D8%AF%D8%AE%D8%AA%D8%B1%DB%8C-%D8%AF%D8%B1-%D9%82%D8%B7%D8%A7%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D8%AB%D8%B1-%D9%BE%D8%A7%D8%A6%D9%88%D9%84%D8%A7-%D9%87%D8%A7%D9%88%DA%A9%DB%8C%D9%86%D8%B2 |title=کتاب دختري در قطار اثر پائولا هاوکينز |website=[[Digikala]] |language=fa |accessdate=16 April 2018}} |Milkan |دخترى در قطار
''Doxtar-i dar Qatâr'' |Mahboobeh Mousavi |- |German{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} |[[Random House]] |''Girl on the Train'' |Christoph Göhler |- |[[Bahasa Indonesia]]{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} |Noura Books Publishing |''The Girl on The Train'' |Inggrid Nimpoeno |- |Italian{{cite web |url=http://www.edizpiemme.it/libri/la-ragazza-del-treno |title=La ragazza del treno |website=Edizioni Piemme |language=it |accessdate=16 April 2018}} |[[Piemme]] |''La ragazza del treno'' |B. Porteri |- |Polish{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} |Świat Książki |''Dziewczyna z pociągu'' |Jan Kraśko |- |Portuguese{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} |Topseller |''A Rapariga no Comboio'' |José João Letria (revised by Diogo Montenegro) |- |Spanish{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} |[[Editorial Planeta]] |''La Chica del Tren'' |Aleix Montoto |- |[[Turkish language|Turkish]]{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} |İthaki Publishing-house |''Trendeki Kız'' |Aslıhan Kuzucan |- |[[Traditional Chinese language|Traditional Chinese]]{{Cite web |url=https://www.booklife.com.tw/列車上的女孩【電影書衣版】/action-products_detail-lid-1-did-4412.htm |title=列車上的女孩 |website=Booklife.com.tw |language=zh |accessdate=16 April 2018}} |Eurasian Publishing Group and Sole Press |列車上的女孩 ''Lièchē shàng de nǚhái'' |Wang Xinxin |- |[[Romanian language|Romanian]]{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} |Editura Trei |''Fata din tren'' |Ionela Chirila |- |[[Bengali language|Bengali]]{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} |Batighar Prokashoni |''The Girl on The Train'' |Kishor Pasha Imon |- |Hebrew{{citation needed|date=August 2016}} |Keter-Books |הבחורה על הרכבת ''HaBahura al HaRakevet'' |Hadasa Handler |- |[[Slovenian Language|Slovene]]{{Cite web |url=http://www.mladinska.com/za_medije/dogodki_za_novinarje/5004 |title=Dekle na vlaku |website=Mladinska knjiga |language=sl-SI |access-date=18 September 2016}} |Mladinska knjiga Založba |''Dekle na vlaku'' |Alenka Ropret |- |Vietnamese{{cite web |url=http://nhanam.vn/sach/co-gai-tren-tau |title=Cô gái trên tàu |website=Nhã Nam.vn |language=vi |accessdate=16 April 2018}} |[[Nhã Nam]] |''Cô gái trên tàu'' |Huyền Vũ |- |Georgian |პალიტრა L |გოგონა მატარებელში |მანანა კვესელავა |- |[[Japanese language|Japanese]]{{cite web |url=http://bookclub.kodansha.co.jp/product?isbn=9784062932226 |title=ガール・オン・ザ・トレイン |website=[[Kodansha]] |language=ja |accessdate=16 April 2018}} |講談社文庫 [[Kodansha]] |{{nihongo|ガール・オン・ザ・トレイン|gāru on za torein}} |{{nihongo|池田 真紀子|Makiko Ikeda}} |- |Greek |Ψυχογιός |Το κορίτσι του τρένου |Αναστάσιος Αργυρίου |- |Hungarian{{Cite web |url=https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/6894204.Tomori_G_bor |title=Tomori Gábor |website=Goodreads.com |language=hu |access-date=16 March 2018}} |XXI. Század Kiadó |A lány a vonaton |Tomori Gábor |} ==Film adaptation== {{main|The Girl on the Train (2016 film)}} The film rights for the novel were acquired in March 2014 by [[DreamWorks|DreamWorks Pictures]] and Marc Platt Productions, with Jared Leboff (a producer at Marc Platt) set to produce.{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/10/02/movies/the-girl-on-the-train-book-movie-adaptation.html |newspaper=The New York Times |title=Movies: 'The Girl on the Train' Movie Adaptation |date=2 October 2016}} [[Tate Taylor]], who directed ''[[The Help (film)|The Help]]'' (2011), was announced as the director of this film in May 2015, with [[Erin Cressida Wilson]] as scriptwriter.{{cite magazine |last1=McNary |first1=Dave |title='The Help' Director Tate Taylor Boards 'Girl on the Train' |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/the-help-director-tate-taylor-boards-girl-on-the-train-1201502918/ |magazine=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] |accessdate=6 June 2015 |date=21 May 2015}} In June 2015, British actress [[Emily Blunt]] was in talks to portray Rachel.{{cite magazine |last1=Kroll |first1=Justin |title=Emily Blunt in Talks to Star in 'The Girl on the Train' Adaptation |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/emily-blunt-girl-on-a-train-dreamworks-1201512611/ |date=4 June 2015 |magazine=Variety |accessdate=6 June 2015}} Author Hawkins said in July 2015 that the film's setting would be moved from the UK to the US.{{cite news |last=Pulver |first=Andrew |url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2015/jul/13/the-girl-on-the-train-film-moved-from-england-to-us-emily-blunt-paula-hawkins |title='The Girl on the Train' film to be set in US not UK |newspaper=The Guardian |date=13 July 2015}} The film began production in the New York City area in October 2015.{{cite web |title=Casting Featured Male Role in DreamWorks Pictures 'The Girl on the Train' Starring Emily Blunt & Chris Evans |url=http://www.auditionsfree.com/2015/casting-featured-male-role-dreamworks-pictures-girl-train-starring-emily-blunt-chris-evans/ |date=22 October 2015 |website=AuditionsFree.com |accessdate=6 December 2015}} The film was released on 7 October 2016.{{cite magazine |last1=McNary |first1=Dave |title=Universal Boards Emily Blunt's 'Girl on the Train' |url=https://variety.com/2015/film/news/the-girl-on-the-train-release-date-emily-blunt-1201663358/ |accessdate=23 December 2015 |magazine=Variety |date=6 December 2015}} It remains mostly faithful to events in the book; the only distinct difference is that Rachel realises the truth about Tom's accusations of her behavior, not because of her own efforts, but through a chance meeting with the wife of Tom's former manager, who reveals that Tom was actually fired from his job because of his numerous affairs at the office, rather than Rachel's having a violent breakdown at a party (In reality, Rachel simply drank too much and passed out in a guest room, until Tom made her leave). == Stage adaptation == A stage adaptation of the novel by Rachel Wagstaff and Duncan Abel made its world premiere in The Courtyard Theatre at the [[West Yorkshire Playhouse]] from 12 May to 9 June 2018. It stars [[Jill Halfpenny]] as Rachel Watson and is directed by Joe Murphy.{{Cite web |url=https://www.wyp.org.uk/latest_news/jill-halfpenny-to-star-in-world-premiere-of-the-girl-on-the-train-at-west-yorkshire-playhouse/ |title=Jill Halfpenny to star in world premiere of The Girl on the Train at West Yorkshire Playhouse |website=West Yorkshire Playhouse |access-date=8 April 2018}} References {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Girl on the train, The}} [[Category:2015 novels]] [[Category:Novels set in London]] [[Category:Fiction with unreliable narrators]] [[Category:British novels adapted into films]] [[Category:Psychotherapy in fiction]] [[Category:Novels about missing people]]

revision.text:
[[File:7 of Diamonds - VanityFair.JPG|thumb|right|7 of Diamonds from the ''Vanity Fair'' deck. [[United States Playing Card Company]]]] A '''transformation playing card''' (sometimes referred to as a transformation deck when assembled into a complete set) is a type of [[playing card]] where an artist incorporates the [[Pip (counting)|pips]] of the non-[[face card]]s into an artistic design. In a classical transformation playing card, the pips retain their standard position and coloration on the card. In some variations, the pips may be different in size, location or color. There is some debate as to whether these cards, often referred to as semi-transformed, should be considered true transformation playing cards.<ref name=gamesetal>{{cite web| last =| first =| authorlink =| coauthors =| title =Transformation Playing Cards - what are they?| work =| publisher =Games et al.| date =| url =http://www.gamesetal.net/transformation-cards/html/transformations.html| format =| doi =| accessdate =2007-06-25| deadurl =yes| archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20070930163303/http://www.gamesetal.net/transformation-cards/html/transformations.html| archivedate =2007-09-30| df =}}</ref>
==History== [[File:7 of hearts - metastasis.JPG|thumb|left|150px|7 of Hearts from ''Metastasis'']] By the 19th century, the standard form for playing cards had become fixed in most of Europe and America. French cards used hearts, diamonds, spades and clubs. German cards used acorns, leaves, hearts and bells. It was at this time that designers in Germany, France and England began to draw small figures around the pips.<ref>{{Cite journal | last = Bauwens | first = Jan | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = Comic Carten | date = | year = | url = | accessdate = | postscript = <!--None--> }}</ref>
The first transformation playing cards were created by D.W. Soltan and D. Berger in 1801 as illustrations for a German edition of [[Hudibras]]. The cards illustrated were the 2 of hearts, 3 of hearts, 5 of hearts and 8 of hearts.<ref>{{cite book | last = Field | first = Albert | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Transformation Playing Cards | publisher = U.S. Games Systems, Inc. | date = 1987 | location = | pages = 6–7 | url = | doi = | isbn = 0-88079-033-4 }}</ref> In 1803, John Nixon published the first complete set (52 cards) of transformed cards. Titled ''Metastasis'', this collection was also published as illustrations on sheets of paper.<ref>{{cite book | last = Field | first = Albert | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Transformation Playing Cards | publisher = U.S. Games Systems, Inc. | date = 1987 | location = | pages = 12–14 | url = | doi = | isbn = 0-88079-033-4 }}</ref> In 1804, J.C. Cotta, a publisher and bookseller in [[Tübingen]], Germany, produced the first set of transformation cards that was published as an actual deck of playing cards. These decks were published as almanacs, in which each of the 52 cards corresponded to one of the 52 weeks of the year.<ref>{{cite book | last = Field | first = Albert | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Transformation Playing Cards | publisher = U.S. Games Systems, Inc. | date = 1987 | location = | pages = 16–18 | url = | doi = | isbn = 0-88079-033-4 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Transforming Playing Cards | work = | publisher = The Marine Stewardship Counsel | date = | url = http://www.msc.org/html/content_1056.htm | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2007-06-25 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070125143445/http://www.msc.org/html/content_1056.htm |archivedate = January 25, 2007}}</ref>
In 1865 Dean and Son published a deck in which the pips have been changed in both size and location, being placed at the artist's whim. Collectors debate as to whether or not this deck should be considered a transformation deck, due to these differences.<ref>{{cite book | last = Field | first = Albert | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Transformation Playing Cards | publisher = U.S. Games Systems, Inc. | date = 1987 | location = | pages = 113–115 | url = | doi = | isbn = 0-88079-033-4 }}</ref> The Dean and Son deck remained the only deck to manipuate the pips until the 1970s, when the practice gained some popularity.<ref>{{cite book | last = Field | first = Albert | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Transformation Playing Cards | publisher = U.S. Games Systems, Inc. | date = 1987 | location = | pages = 199 | url = | doi = | isbn = 0-88079-033-4 }}</ref> Today, cards that do not strictly adhere to standard pip placement, size and color are referred to as semi-transformation playing cards.
An article entitled "Playing Card Squiggles." was published in the December 1910 issue of ''[[Strand Magazine]]''. Several ''Cotta'' cards were pictured, erroneously attributed to an unnamed French artist. ''Strand'' subsequently asked its readers to submit their own designs for card squiggles, which the magazine periodically published. [[John Butler Yeats]] was one of the first to contribute a card design to the magazine. The feature remained popular for some time.<ref name=gamesetal/><ref>{{cite book | last = Field | first = Albert | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Transformation Playing Cards | publisher = U.S. Games Systems, Inc. | date = 1987 | location = | pages = 187–191 | url = | doi = | isbn = 0-88079-033-4 }}</ref>
[[File:3 of Clubs - Key to the Kingdom.JPG|thumb|left|150px|''[[Three Blind Mice]]'' as portrayed on the 3 of Clubs from ''The Key to the Kingdom'']]
Some have estimated that around 70 different transformation decks were created throughout the entire nineteenth century, which by modern standards is a relatively small number. This period of time also witnessed progression with this art-form. By the late 19th century more colourful and creative transformation decks by Vanity Fair and Harlequin appeared, which showed pips incorporated into artwork that depicted people dining, skating, playing tennis and riding bicycles.<ref>https://playingcarddecks.com/blogs/all-in/creative-genius-of-transformation-playing-cards</ref>
==Contemporary designs== Transformation playing cards like ''Art for the Earth'' by The [[Friends of the Earth]] and ''Under the Sea'' by the Marine Stewardship Counsel, are created for charity purposes, with different artists contributing art for each card. Similarly, other collective projects like ''Ultimate Deck'' from Dan & Dave and Stranger & Stranger or the series from Black Rock Collective brings multiple artists together to create semi-transformation decks.
One of the more notable contemporary sets is the award winning ''The Key to the Kingdom,'' a semi-transformation deck commissioned by London's [[V&A Museum of Childhood]] and created by Tony Meeuwissen. It won the [[WH Smith Literary Award]] for best illustration and The Designers and Art Directory Association of London gold award.<ref>{{cite web | title = Tony Shows His Tricks | publisher = South Wales Argus | url = http://archive.southwalesargus.co.uk/2002/10/24/70236.html | accessdate = 2007-07-02 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100209013418/http://archive.southwalesargus.co.uk/2002/10/24/70236.html | archivedate = 2010-02-09 | df = }}</ref> This set of cards was created around the theme of [[nursery rhyme]]s and [[poem]]s. The cards were sold with a book containing each poem and a picture of the corresponding card on the opposite page. Additionally, the deck was constructed as a [[puzzle contest]] laid out in the form of an original poem. The poem gave clues to pick certain cards, which then could be decrypted into a secret message. The prize of $10,000 and a golden key was won by Susan Kavanagh of Essex.<ref>{{cite web | title = The Key to the Kingdom - Solution | publisher = The Armchair Treasure Hunt Club | accessdate = 2007-07-18 | url = http://www.treasureclub.net/publichunts/keytothekingdom/index.html}}</ref>
With the advent of [[Kickstarter]] and other crowdfunded websites, individual artists are more easily able to bring transformation and semi-transformation decks to the public. Notable examples include the series of semi-transformation decks from Emmanuel Jose (including ''Curator'' and ''Clipped Wings'') and Dave Ufford's traditional transformation EclecDeck.
==See also== * [[Minor Arcana]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.cs.man.ac.uk/~daf/i-p-c-s.org/faq/transformation.php The International Playing Card Society] - Gallery of various transformations of the four of diamonds. *[http://www.folioboutique.com/tonymeeuwissen Folio Boutique - Tony Meeuwissen] - Gallery of cards from Tony Meeuwissen's transformation deck, The Key of the Kingdom. *[http://www.gamesetal.net/tro.html Games et al showing a great selection of Transformation Playing Cards] A large selection of transformation playing cards. *[https://playingcarddecks.com/blogs/all-in/creative-genius-of-transformation-playing-cards The Creative Genius of Transformation Playing Cards] - Good article with background information on Transformation cards. *[https://playingcarddecks.com/blogs/all-in/20th-century-transformation-playing-cards In-depth article on 20th Century Transformation Playing Cards] *[https://playingcarddecks.com/blogs/all-in/modern-era-transformation-playing-cards In-depth article on the Modern Era of transformation Playing Cards] [[Category:Playing cards]] [[Category:History of card decks]] [[Category:Graphic design]] {{good article}}

revision.comment: Trials HD never released on Windows PC. It's exclusive to Xbox 360
revision.text:
{{good article}} {{Infobox video game | title = Trials HD | developer = [[RedLynx]] | image = Trialshd.jpg | publisher = [[Microsoft Studios (game studio)|Microsoft Game Studios]]{{cite web |url=http://marketplace.xbox.com/en-CA/Product/Trials-HD/66acd000-77fe-1000-9115-d8025841095a |title=Trials HD Game Downloads |publisher=[[Xbox.com]] |accessdate=2011-01-07}}
[[Ubisoft]] (PC) | series = ''[[Trials (series)|Trials]]'' | engine = [[Bullet (software)|Bullet Physics Library]]{{cite web |url=http://interviews.teamxbox.com/xbox/2459/Trials-HD-Developer-Interview/p1 |title=Trials HD Developer Interview |accessdate=2009-11-14 |first=Dale |last=Nardozzi |date=2009-08-06 |publisher=TeamXbox |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100211140603/http://interviews.teamxbox.com/xbox/2459/Trials-HD-Developer-Interview/p1/ |archivedate=2010-02-11 |df= }} | platforms = [[Xbox 360]] ([[Xbox Live Arcade|XBLA]])
| released = '''Xbox 360'''
August 12, 2009
| genre = [[Racing video game|Racing game]], [[computer puzzle game|Puzzle game]] | modes = [[Single-player]] }} '''''Trials HD''''' is an [[Xbox Live Arcade]] game developed by [[RedLynx]] and published by [[Microsoft Studios (game studio)|Microsoft Game Studios]]. It was released on August 12, 2009 as part of the second annual [[Summer of Arcade|Xbox Live Summer of Arcade]] and was later re-released in a retail pack alongside ''[[Limbo (video game)|Limbo]]'' and ''[['Splosion Man]]'' in April 2011. It is a [[2.5D]] [[puzzle video game|puzzle]]/[[racing video game|racing]] game. The player must guide a [[Motorcycle trials|trial motorcycle]] with exaggerated physics through various obstacles to reach each stage's finish line. On September 6, 2012 it was announced that a [[Microsoft Windows]] version of ''Trials HD'' would be bundled inside a special version of ''[[Trials Evolution]]'', dubbed ''Trials Evolution: Gold Edition''—although this version changes the physics of the game. It is the third game in the series. On February 11, 2016, [[Microsoft]] added ''Trials HD'' as part of its backwards compatibility program for [[Xbox One]]. ==Gameplay== [[File:TrialsHDscreenshot.png|thumb|left|In ''Trials HD'' players must manipulate the rider and motorcycle to traverse obstacles and objects found throughout each level.]] In ''Trials HD'' the player controls a rider on a physics-based motorcycle from the start of the level to the end while navigating a number of [[Obstacle course|obstacles]]. The objective is to complete the course as fast as possible and with as few crashes, known in the game as faults, as possible.{{Cite web |url=http://previews.teamxbox.com/xbox-360/2385/Trials-HD/p1/ |publisher=[[TeamXbox]] |date=2009-07-20 |first=Dale |last=Nardozzi |title=Trials HD Hands-On Preview (Xbox 360) |accessdate=2010-10-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101010080746/http://previews.teamxbox.com/xbox-360/2385/Trials-HD/p1/ |archivedate=2010-10-10 |df= }} The game uses [[3D computer graphics|3D graphics]], but is played on a [[2.5D|2D]] plane, so the rider can only move forwards and backwards. Players can also control the bike's pitch at slow speeds or while in the air.{{Cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/xbox360/driving/trialshd/news.html?sid=6213216&mode=previews |title=Trials HD Hands-On |date=2009-07-10 |first=Guy |last=Cocker |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=2010-10-12}} The game has a variety of courses in a range of difficulties from beginner to extreme. There are a total of thirty-five courses in the game, and players can replay completed courses to attempt a faster time. Tournament mode sees the player attempt to complete a number of courses in sequence, trying to achieve a fast overall time with minimal faults. Twelve skill games can also be unlocked which place the player in different challenges.{{Cite web |publisher=[[Videogamer.com]] |accessdate=2010-10-12 |url=http://www.videogamer.com/xbox360/trials/review.html |first=Tim |last=Orry |title=Trials HD Review |date=2009-08-12}} These include things such as riding inside or on top of a large spherical cage, achieving as many flips as possible within a set time limit, or towing a trailer with two large bombs as far as possible while keeping them from exploding by impact. Players earn medals based on their completion time, number of faults, and in the case of skill games, other specialized criteria. When connected to [[Xbox Live]], the player can view their performance in relation to players in their friends list. This is done by an in-game meter which displays the closest friend to the player's time which adjusts based on whether the player is leading or trailing the friend's course time. ''Trials HD'' includes a level editor that allows players to construct their own courses and share them with players in their friends list. Every course in the game was created using the level editor, which allows users to create professional-quality levels. It also features [[Game ladder|leaderboards]] for each of the game's courses and modes. For each course the fastest five thousand times are able to be viewed as replays. During the replay the viewer can view that recorded player's controller presses, allowing them to learn patterns and skills from it. ==Development and marketing== ''Trials HD'' is the second [[2.5D]] game in the ''Trials'' series, following ''[[Trials 2: Second Edition]]''. The game is based on the popular [[Browser game|flash games]] from the same series.{{cite web |url=http://www.redlynx.com/index.php?id=520 |publisher=[[RedLynx]] |accessdate=2011-02-20 |title=RedLynx Games}} It was released on August 12, 2009 as part of the second annual [[Xbox Live Arcade|Xbox Live Summer of Arcade]].{{cite web |url=http://xboxlive.ign.com/articles/100/1002344p1.html |title=Summer of Arcade Dates Revealed |publisher=[[IGN]] |first=Daemon |last=Hatfield |date=2009-07-29 |accessdate=2009-08-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090712044556/http://xboxlive.ign.com/articles/100/1002344p1.html |archivedate=2009-07-12 |df= }} RedLynx developed ''Trials HD'' using an in-house engine coupled with a modified version of [[Bullet (software)|''Bullet Physics Library'']] which was optimized to utilize the Xbox 360's CPU and vector units. RedLynx applied the physics system to give a realistic feel, but to maintain the enjoyment of a video game, they tweaked the physics to "bend the reality in just the proper way." RedLynx saw this as a "crucial thing in making Trials such a fun and addictive game" Previous ''Trials'' games used a much simpler in-house physics engine, however for ''Trials HD'' developers opted to use the ''Bullet'' library and devote one of the 360's cpu cores entirely to physics.{{Cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/digitalfoundry-tech-interview-trials-hd |title=Tech Interview: Trials HD |date=2009-09-12 |accessdate=2010-10-11 |publisher=[[Eurogamer]]}} Developers also improved on the ''Trials 2'' engine by adding more advanced lighting and real time soft shadows. [[File:TrialsHD levelEditor.png|thumb|''Trials HD'' levels were created using the same in-game editor which players can also use to create and share their own levels.]] Levels created for ''Trials HD'' were designed using the same in-game level editor that allows players to make user-based content. All of the tools and abilities the developers had at their disposal can be used by the community. In an interview with [[Eurogamer]], RedLynx's Lead Programmer Sebastian Aaltonen stated that there were no plans to port the game to other platforms, adding "''Trials HD'' technology has been specially designed for the Xbox 360 feature-set." The voice work for the game was done by three [[Pennsylvania]]n voice actors, [[Rake Yohn]], [[Brandon DiCamillo]], and Art Webb.{{Cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DymAMwFWSFI |accessdate=2010-10-12 |publisher=RedLynxTV via [[YouTube]] |date=2010-07-30 |title=RedLynx TV - Episode 5}} ''Trials HD'' was announced June 1, 2009 at a Microsoft luncheon during [[E3 2009]].{{Cite web |url=http://xboxlive.ign.com/articles/988/988799p1.html |title=Trials HD Coming to XBLA |publisher=IGN |first=Charles |last=Onyett |date=2009-06-01 |accessdate=2011-02-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120404111335/http://xboxlive.ign.com/articles/988/988799p1.html |archivedate=2012-04-04 |df= }} It was released August 12, 2009 as part of the Xbox Live Summer of Arcade.{{Cite web |url=http://games.ign.com/articles/101/1012654p1.html |first=Ryan |last=Geddes |publisher=IGN |accessdate=2011-02-06 |title=Out This Week: August 10-14, 2009 |date=2009-08-10}} On December 23, 2009 the first [[downloadable content]], known as the ''Trials HD Big Pack'', was released. The content features twenty three new courses, new objects for the game's built-in level creator and new achievements.{{Cite web |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2009/12/15/trials-hd-dlc-detailed-new-trailer/ |accessdate=2010-10-13 |date=2009-12-15 |title=Trials HD DLC detailed, new trailer |first=Richard |last=Mitchell |publisher=Joystiq}} A second downloadable content pack was announced for the game in July 2010. The ''Trials HD Big Thrills Pack'' features forty new courses made by RedLynx, but unlike the ''Trials HD Big Pack'' it also features ten user created courses. These ten courses are to be decided from entries to the Big Thrills Track Creation Competition.{{cite web |url=http://www.redlynxgame.com/forum/viewtopic.php?f=28&t=4225 |title=Trials HD Big Thrills Track Creation Competition |author=jenkki |publisher=RedLynx |date=2010-07-20 |accessdate=2010-07-21 }} The top three contestants were awarded prizes of $5,000, $3,000, and $1,000, respectively.{{Cite web |url=http://www.joystiq.com/2010/07/20/trials-hd-dlc-to-deliver-big-thrills-later-this-year/ |accessdate=2010-10-12 |publisher=Joystiq |date=2010-07-20 |title=Trials HD DLC to deliver 'Big Thrills' later this year |first=David |last=Hinkle}} Winners were announced on November 15, 2010.{{Cite web |url=https://microsoft.promo.eprize.com/trialshd/ |publisher=[[Microsoft]] and RedLynx |accessdate=2010-10-12 |title=Big Thrills! Trials HD Track Creator Challenge |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110208100159/https://microsoft.promo.eprize.com/trialshd/ |archivedate=2011-02-08 |df= }} The ''Big Thrills Pack'' was released December 1, 2010. ==Reception and sales== {{Video game reviews | title = ''Trials HD'' | GR = 86.1% | MC = 86/100 | 1UP = A-{{cite web |url=http://www.1up.com/reviews/trials-hd-review |title=Trials HD (Xbox 360) |first=Yara |last=Elmjouie |date=2009-08-24 |accessdate=2010-07-21 |publisher=[[1UP.com]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629033048/http://www.1up.com/reviews/trials-hd-review |archivedate=2011-06-29 |df= }} | EuroG = 9/10 | GamePro = 4.5/5{{Cite web |url=http://gparcade.blogfaction.com/article/110393/xbla-review-trials-hd/ |publisher=''[[GamePro]]'' |accessdate=2010-10-11 |title=XBLA Review - Trials HD |first=Sean |last=Ely |date=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111006170603/http://gparcade.blogfaction.com/article/110393/xbla-review-trials-hd/ |archivedate=2011-10-06 |df= }} | GT = 8.5/10 | IGN = 8.3/10 | OXM = 8/10{{Cite web |url=http://www.oxmonline.com/article/reviews/xbox-live-arcade/s-z/trials-hd |publisher=''[[Official Xbox Magazine]]'' |accessdate=2010-10-11 |date=2009-08-13 |title=Trials HD |first=Ryan |last=McCaffrey}} | PALGN = 8/10{{Cite web |url=http://palgn.com.au/xbox-360/15063/trials-hd-review/ |publisher=[[PALGN]] |accessdate=2010-10-11 |title=Trials HD Review |author=Toastfarmer |date=2009-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130115020730/http://palgn.com.au/xbox-360/15063/trials-hd-review/ |archivedate=2013-01-15 |df= }} | award1Pub = [[Xbox Live]] | award1 = Best Overall Arcade Game,
Best Innovation (2009) }} ''Trials HD'' was generally well received by game critics. Aggregate websites [[GameRankings]] and [[Metacritic]] report average scores of 86.1% and 86/100, respectively.{{cite web |url=http://www.gamerankings.com/xbox360/960538-trials-hd/index.html |title=Trials HD for Xbox 360 |accessdate=2010-07-21 |publisher=[[GameRankings]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/xbox-360/trials-hd |title=Trials HD for Xbox 360 Reviews, Ratings, Credits, and More at Metacritic |accessdate=2010-07-21 |publisher=[[Metacritic]]}} In its first month, the title sold over 300 thousand units.{{Cite web |url=http://www.gamasutra.com/view/news/25381/RedLynxs_Trials_HD_Sells_300000_On_Xbox_Live_Arcade.php |title=RedLynx's Trials HD Sells 300,000 On Xbox Live Arcade |first=Kris |last=Graft |date=2009-09-23 |accessdate=2010-10-12 |publisher=[[Gamasutra]]}} On September 14, 2010 RedLynx announced that ''Trials HD'' had surpassed 1.3 million units in sales.{{Cite web |url=http://www.gamerbytes.com/2011/01/indepth_xbox_live_arcade_sales_18.php#more |title=XBLA: In-Depth: Xbox Live Arcade Sales Analysis For All Of 2010 |first=Ryan |last=Langley |publisher=Gamerbytes |date=2011-01-28 |accessdate=2011-01-31}} Sales of the first downloadable content pack have also exceeded 360 thousand, with the second pack selling over 90 thousand units.{{cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/trials-hd-voted-best-xbla-game |title=Trials HD voted best XBLA game |first=Robert |last=Purchese |date=2009-04-07 |accessdate=2010-10-11 |publisher=Eurogamer}} On May 27, 2011 RedLynx announced that sales have exceeded two million units.{{cite web |title=Trials HD Reaches Two Million Unit Sales |url=http://redlynx.com/press/96-trials-hd-reaches-two-million-unit-sales/ |publisher=RedLynx |accessdate=2011-05-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110601100626/http://redlynx.com/press/96-trials-hd-reaches-two-million-unit-sales |archivedate=2011-06-01 |df= }} In 2009, ''Trials HD'' received two awards voted on by the Xbox 360 community, Best Overall Arcade Game and Best Innovation.{{cite web | title=XBLA Gamers Pick XBLA Favorites | url=http://xboxlive.ign.com/articles/108/1082104p1.html | publisher=IGN | accessdate=2010-04-07 | date=2010-04-06 | first=Daemon | last=Hatfield | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100409080806/http://xboxlive.ign.com/articles/108/1082104p1.html | archivedate=2010-04-09 | df= }} In a September 2010 ranking, [[IGN]] listed ''Trials HD'' sixteenth in their top twenty-five Xbox Live Arcade titles of all time.{{cite web |url=http://xboxlive.ign.com/articles/112/1120887p1.html |title=The Top 25 Xbox Live Arcade Games |publisher=IGN |date=2010-09-16 |accessdate=2010-09-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100918065519/http://xboxlive.ign.com/articles/112/1120887p1.html |archivedate=2010-09-18 |df= }} It was also awarded a perfect score by ''[[Xbox World 360]]'' magazine."Xbox World 360" (Oct 2009) Reviewers generally praised the game's replay value. [[IGN]]'s Daemon Hatfield remarked that ''Trials HD'' had "truckloads of content" adding that the game's features "really take advantage of what can be done with Xbox Live."{{cite web |url=http://xboxlive.ign.com/articles/101/1012642p1.html |title=Trials HD Review: This is no easy rider |first=Daemon |last=Hatfield |date=2009-08-10 |accessdate=2010-07-21 |publisher=IGN |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101214065945/http://xboxlive.ign.com/articles/101/1012642p1.html |archivedate=2010-12-14 |df= }} [[GameTrailers]] staff also praised the amount of content in the game stating that it was an excellent value for the price.{{Cite web |url=http://www.gametrailers.com/gamereview.php?id=11618 |publisher=[[GameTrailers]] |accessdate=2010-10-11 |date=2009-08-12 |title=Trials HD: Review}} [[Eurogamer]] stated that "it's a game built for endless replay and community expansion beyond that."{{cite web |url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/trials-hd-review |title= Trials HD Xbox 360 Review |first=Tom |last=Bramwell |date=2009-08-10 |accessdate=2010-07-21 |publisher=Eurogamer}} The game's leaderboards, especially the ability to have a view of where other players were at a certain time during a run, were widely praised by Brad Shoemaker of [[Giant Bomb]].{{cite web |title=Trials HD Review |url=http://www.giantbomb.com/trials-hd/61-26923/reviews/ |publisher=[[Giant Bomb]] |accessdate=2010-07-22 |date=2010-09-23 |first=Brad |last=Shoemaker}} One of the primary criticisms given by critics was ''Trials HD''{{'}}s steep difficulty curve. Brad Shoemaker of Giant Bomb stated that he wished the difficulty curve was "a little smoother." Daemon Hatfield of IGN further commented on the game's difficulty, stating "It's when you get stuck trying to get over some small hill and you see that fault counter in the top left corner counting up [...] that the game starts being more frustrating than fun." [[GameSpy]]'s Anthony Gallegos added that the "limited number of tries per track feels arbitrary."{{Cite web |url=http://xbox360.gamespy.com/xbox-360/trials-hd/1013512p1.html |title=The Consensus: Trials HD Review |accessdate=2010-10-13 |first=Anthony |last=Gallegos |date=2009-08-12 |publisher=[[GameSpy]]}} He was also critical of the game's file sharing system, noting that instead of a repository from which to download tracks that sharing is limited to those in the player's friends list. Tom Mc Shea of [[GameSpot]] also agreed that the difficulty on the latter tracks was "ridiculously hard" and shared disappointment in the file sharing system.{{Cite web |url=http://www.gamespot.com/xbox360/driving/trialshd/review.html |title=Trials HD Review |first=Tom |last=Mc Shea |publisher=[[GameSpot]] |accessdate=2010-10-13 |date=2009-08-12}} {{-}} ==See also== {{Portal|Video games}} *''[[Trials Evolution]]'' ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110709101410/http://www.redlynx.com/games/xbox-360/trials-hd Official Website] *''[http://marketplace.xbox.com/en-US/Product/Trials-HD/66acd000-77fe-1000-9115-d8025841095a Trials HD]'' at [[xbox.com]] {{Trials}} [[Category:2009 video games]] [[Category:Microsoft games]] [[Category:Motorcycle video games]] [[Category:Racing video games]] [[Category:Video games developed in Finland]] [[Category:Video games with 2.5D graphics]] [[Category:Video games with expansion packs]] [[Category:Xbox 360 Live Arcade games]] [[Category:Windows games]] [[Category:Xbox 360 games]] [[Category:Video games with user-generated gameplay content]] [[Category:RedLynx games]] [[Category:Trials (series)]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta2)
revision.text:
A '''visual narrative''' (also '''visual storytelling''')<ref>Tony C. Caputo, ''Visual Storytelling: The Art and Technique'', Watson-Guptill Publications, 2003.</ref> is a story told primarily through the use of visual media. The story may be told using still [[photography]], [[illustration]], or [[video]], and can be enhanced with [[graphics]], music, voice and other audio.
==Overview<!--'Visual narratology' redirects here-->== The term "visual narrative" has been used to describe several genres of visual storytelling, from news and information ([[photojournalism]], the [[photo essay]], the [[documentary film]]) to entertainment (art, movies, television, [[comic book]]s, the [[graphic novel]]). In short, any kind of a story, told visually, is a visual narrative.
The visual narrative has also been of interest to the academic community as scholars, thinkers and educators have sought to understand the impact and power of image and narrative in individuals and societies. The corresponding discipline is called '''visual [[narratology]]'''<!--boldface per WP:R#PLA-->.<ref>''[http://www.imageandnarrative.be Image <nowiki>[&]</nowiki> Narrative]'' – "a peer-reviewed [[e-journal]] on visual narratology in the broadest sense of the term".</ref>
Distinguishing characteristics of the visual narrative include: *a persuasive story with a point of view *high quality images, still or moving *subject matter with pressing social, environmental, or spiritual value *an appeal (explicit or implicit) for transformation in attitudes and behaviors
==See also== * [[Multiliteracy]] * [[Sequential art]] * [[Visual literacy]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://mfavisualnarrative.sva.edu/ MFA in Visual Narrative at The School of Visual Arts] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121122003330/http://knowledgenetwork.alumni.msu.edu/msu-broad-art-museum/eliandedythebroadhavespenttheirlifetimegivingback.html Michigan State University Professor Karl Gude and Visual Storytelling by MSUAA Knowledge Network]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Visual Narrative}} [[Category:Visual arts]] [[Category:Narrative forms]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox recurring event |name = Wisconsin State Fair |logo = |image = Wisconsin State Fair Logo.png |imagesize = 200px |caption = The State Fair's "snowflake" logo, in use since 1972 to advertise the year-round use of Wisconsin State Fair Park{{cite news|url=http://www.jsonline.com/business/118623999.html|title=State Fair Park logo gets new look|last=Walker|first=Don|date=25 March 2011|work=[[Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]]|accessdate=14 August 2013}} |location = [[West Allis, Wisconsin|West Allis, WI]] |years_active = 160[http://www.wistatefair.com/fair_info/history.html Wisconsin State Fair History] |founded = 1851 |dates = 11 Days |genre = [[State fair]] |attendance = 1,030,811 in 2014[http://www.jsonline.com/entertainment/festivals/wisconsin-state-fair-reports-record-attendance-for-2014-b99329872z1-271058281.html] |patron = |website = [http://www.wistatefair.com www.wistatefair.com] }} [[File:Wisconsin State Fair.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Grandstand Avenue, Wisconsin State Fair]] [[File:Wisconsin State Fair - 1981.jpg|thumb|300px|right|[[Miller Brewing]] race car on display]] The '''Wisconsin State Fair''' is an annual event held at the [[Wisconsin State Fair Park]] in [[West Allis, Wisconsin]], a suburb of [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin|Milwaukee]]. The modern [[state fair|fair]] takes place in August (occasionally beginning late July) and lasts 11 days. ==History== The first Wisconsin State Fair was held in 1851 in [[Janesville, Wisconsin|Janesville]], with approximately 13,000 to 18,000 people in attendance.[http://www.wistatefair.com/fair_info/history.html History] Sponsored by the state’s Agricultural Society, it was held on a six-acre plot along the banks of the [[Rock River (Mississippi River)|Rock River]]. It featured a 200-pound squash and a quarter-acre plowing competition with teams of horses and oxen. It was reportedly the largest gathering in Wisconsin history.[http://www.wistatefair.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/2012/07/Wisconsin-State-Fair-History.pdf Wisconsin State Fair History] When the second fair was held in Milwaukee in 1852, fairgoers took their carriages for rides around the Cold Spring Race Course. Abraham Lincoln was invited to give the annual oration at the fair in 1859. He spoke on the principles of free labor - farmers and their families working for themselves without the use of hired labor - and of the interconnectedness of farmers, merchants, and other businesses. He advised farmers to embrace new methods of agriculture, with the goal of raising the standard of living.Eric Foner. ''The Fiery Trial: Abraham Lincoln and American Slavery''. New York: Norton, 2010, p. 115.[[Benjamin P. Thomas]]. ''Abraham Lincoln: A Biography''. Carbondale: Southern Illinois University Press, 1952, pp. 196-197. The fair added new attractions each year, and in 1869, there was a fire engine demonstration where boxes, barrels and a large wooden building were set aflame. For decades, the fair moved from city to city, including Janesville, Watertown, Fond du Lac, Madison and Milwaukee, until 1892, when it was first held at its permanent and present location at Wisconsin State Fair Park. During the 2011 fair, some adolescent African Americans formed a violent [[flash mob]] and began attacking fairgoers, with some witnesses stating that the attacks were racially-motivated.{{cite news |author= |date=13 August 2014 |title=Wis. State Fair Latest Target Of Violent Flash Mobs |url=https://www.npr.org/2011/08/13/139600667/wis-state-fair-latest-target-of-violent-flash-mobs |newspaper=NPR |accessdate=August 21, 2014}}{{cite news |title=Witnesses describe mobs, some people claim racially-charged attacks |url=http://www.todaystmj4.com/news/local/126825018.html |newspaper=WTmj |date=August 5, 2011 |accessdate=January 5, 2012}}
{{cite news |title=Questions Arise Over Whether 'Flash Mob' Attacks in U.S. Cities Motivated by Race |url=http://www.foxnews.com/us/2011/08/10/flashmob-attacks-in-us-cities-raise-questions-over-possible-race-motivation/ |publisher=Fox News |date=August 10, 2011 |accessdate=January 4, 2012}}
{{cite book|author=Jeffrey Ian Ross|title=Encyclopedia of Street Crime in America|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GR5zAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA163|date=28 March 2013|publisher=SAGE Publications|isbn=978-1-4522-7445-4|page=163}} Eighteen people, including seven police officers, were injured during the event.{{cite news |title=Wisconsin Teen Arrested for Hate Crime and City Blames Black Families: In response to the recent violent flash-mob attacks in Milwaukee, the Common Council uses African-Americans in the community as a scapegoat. |author=Danielle Wright |url=http://www.bet.com/news/national/2011/08/12/wisconsin-teen-arrested-for-hate-crime-and-city-blames-black-families.html |newspaper=[[Black Entertainment Television|BET]] |date=August 12, 2011 |accessdate=January 5, 2012}} In response, fair managers added a youth curfew and worked with civic and youth leaders to prevent a recurrence.{{cite news |last=Williams |first=Justin |title=Crews make last minute preparations before State Fair gates open |url=http://fox6now.com/2012/08/01/state-fair-gates-open-thursday-august-2nd/ |newspaper=WITI |location=Green Bay, Wisconsin |date=1 August 2012 |access-date=5 June 2015 }} == The Milwaukee Mile == [[The Milwaukee Mile]] is a one-mile paved [[oval track racing|oval]] racing circuit on the grounds of the State Fair. It is the oldest continuously-operated motor racing circuit in the world.Wisc. State Fair Park http://www.milwaukeemile.com/event_planning/mile.html Feb. 22, 2013 Racing or exhibition events are often held on the circuit in conjunction with the state fair. == Events and entertainment == {{refimprove section|date=August 2014}} Yearly features at the fair include a wide variety of vendors, many local and national bands, the [[Kids From Wisconsin]], and a large assortment of food and drink, including [[Profiterole|cream puffs]],{{cite web |author= |date=20 August 2013 |title=Which State Fair Food Is Your Guilty Pleasure? |url=https://www.pbs.org/food/features/state-fair-foods/ |website=pbs.org |publisher= Public Broadcasting Service |accessdate=22 August 2014 }} which are one of the fair's most popular attractions. In 2010, the Wisconsin State Fair introduced Comet 2, a forty-foot roller coaster. New in 2012, the Wisconsin State Fair took over the Midway, creating Spin City, a collection of independently contracted rides including the Sizzler, the Freak Out, and the Stratosphere, a 200-foot-tall swing ride. The Main Stage features headline performance every evening of the fair. Many local bands can also be seen on smaller stages and pavilions located throughout the grounds. Agricultural exhibits of horses, cattle, sheep, chickens and other animals are featured every year at the fair. The Wisconsin State Fair is also home of the Wisconsin Wine Garden. Established in 1996 by the then ten member-wineries of the [[Wisconsin Winery Association]], the Wine Garden features wines from dozens of Wisconsin wineries. ==Fairgoer demographics== *Average age of a fairgoer: 40[http://www.wistatefair.com/pdfs/sponsor/2010_Wisconsin_State_Fair_Attendance_&_Demographics.pdf 2010 Wisconsin State Fair Attendance and Demographics] *84% of fairgoers reside in [[Wisconsin]] – half of them live in metropolitan Milwaukee *Average visits to the fair: 3 times *Average hours spent at the fair: 5 - 7 hours ==Notable attendance records== *Attendance record: 1,037,982 in 2018http://www.jsonline.com/entertainment/festivals/wisconsin-state-fair-reports-record-attendance-for-2014-b99329872z1-271058281.html *Opening-day record: 98,625 in 2009 ==See also== *[[Northern Wisconsin State Fair]] *[[Central Wisconsin State Fair]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} == Further reading == * Crump, Gordon. "[https://books.google.com/books?id=0x8EAAAAMBAJ&lpg=PA30&dq=%22wisconsin%20state%20fair%22&pg=PA30#v=onepage&q=wisconsin&f=false Baits Trap with Cheese: State Products Sell Fair]", ''The Billboard'', November 29, 1947, p. 30. * Economics Research Associates. ''Economic Impact of the Wisconsin State Fair and Non-Fair Events, 1979''. West Allis, WI: Wisconsin State Fair Park, 1980. * Gordon, Julie. ''State Fair Park: An Evaluation''. Madison, WI: Wisconsin Legislative Audit Bureau, 2003. * Kapler, Joe. "[http://content.wisconsinhistory.org/cdm/ref/collection/wmh/id/50769 Preserving the 'Big Picture' for Wisconsin: The 1948 Centennial Fair Murals]". ''Wisconsin Magazine of History'', vol. 95, no. 1 (Autumn 2011): 26-35. * Lathrop, John H. "Address Delivered at the First Annual Fair of the State Agricultural Society, Held at Janesville, Wisconsin: October 2, 1851". Milwaukee: ''Daily Sentinel'' Print, 1851. * Lincoln, Abraham. ''Lincoln on Agriculture: Address, Wisconsin State Agricultural Society, State Fair, Milwaukee, September 30, 1859''. Madison: Lincoln Fellowship of Wisconsin, 1943. * Ryan, John W. ''The Wisconsin State Fair: Its Modern Role and Objectives. A Report to Wisconsin Department of Agriculture''. Madison: University Extension Division, 1960. * ''State Fair Commemorative Cookbook: Featuring 150 Award-Winning Recipes''. West Allis, WI: Wisconsin State Fair, 2001. * ''Wisconsin State Fair: 1979 Visitor Study''. Madison, WI: University of Wisconsin-Extension, 1980. * Wisconsin State Fair Park Public Relations Department. ''Wisconsin State Fair: A Brief History of the Wisconsin State Fair''. West Allis, WI: Wisconsin State Fair Park, 1990. * Zimmerman, Jerry. ''150 Years of the Wisconsin State Fair: An Illustrated History, 1851-2001''. West Allis, WI: Wisconsin State Fair Park, 2001. ==External links== * [http://www.wistatefair.com/ Wisconsin State Fair Park website] * [http://www.wsfpfoundation.org/ Wisconsin State Fair Park Foundation Website] * [http://www.wisconsinhistory.org/museum/exhibits/statefairmural/index.asp 1948 Wisconsin State Fair Murals] {{coord missing|Wisconsin}} [[Category:Wisconsin State Fair|*]] [[Category:West Allis, Wisconsin]] [[Category:State fairs]] [[Category:Wisconsin culture]] [[Category:Tourism in Wisconsin]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Milwaukee County, Wisconsin]] [[Category:Traveling carnivals]] [[Category:Festivals established in 1851]]

revision.comment: +img
revision.text:
[[File:Zina Saunders on Count Gore De Vol.jpg|right|thumb|Zina Saunders in 2009]] '''Zina Saunders''' (born August 30, 1953) is a Manhattan-based artist, writer, animator and educator. Her book ''Overlooked New York'', a collection of interviews, profiles and portraits, was published in 2009.
==Life and work== A native New Yorker, Zina Saunders is the daughter of illustrator [[Norman Saunders]].<ref name="newstimes2014">Kasey Burke (February 14, 2014) [http://www.newstimes.com/news/article/Illustrator-Zina-Saunders-to-talk-at-WCSU-5229759.php "Illustrator Zina Saunders to talk at WCSU"], ''News Times'' (Danbury, CT). Retrieved 2014-03-30.</ref> She attended [[The High School of Music and Art|High School of Music and Art]] and [[Cooper Union]] (dropping out a short way into the course)<ref name="newstimes2014" /> but also learned much about painting and commercial art from her father. She has illustrated for a variety of publishers ([[Simon & Schuster]], [[Random House]], [[Scholastic Books]], [[Oxford University Press]]), while contributing to magazines, including ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'',<ref name="newstimes2014" /> ''[[The New York Times|The New York Times Sunday Book Review]]'', ''[[Time Out (company)|Time Out New York]]'' and ''Outré''.<ref>[http://www.filmfax.com/outre/outre.html ''Outré''] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823185530/http://www.filmfax.com/outre/outre.html |date=August 23, 2007 }}</ref>
Her book ''Overlooked New York'' (2009) is a collection of interviews, profiles and portraits of diverse New York subcultures and hobbyists.<ref>Holly Tsang (January 12, 2010) [http://www.queensledger.com/view/full_story/5532149/article-Overlooked-New-Yorkers--Zina-Saunders-Takes-a-Closer-Look?instance=lead_story_left_column "Overlooked New Yorkers: Zina Saunders Takes a Closer Look"], ''Queens Ledger'' (Queens, New York). Retrieved 2014-03-30.</ref> Subjects include amateur astronomers, [[Bicycle messenger|bike messengers]], carnival costume designers, cricket players, [[pigeon keeping|keepers of rooftop pigeon coops]], kite flyers, scuba divers, [[busking|street performers, subway musicians]] and urban gardeners. The project began in the fall of 2004 with her observation of colorful, decorative bicycles.<ref>[http://www.overlookednewyork.com/schwinn/index.html Overlooked New York: Puerto Rican Schwinn Club] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061022164144/http://www.overlookednewyork.com/schwinn/index.html |date=October 22, 2006 }}</ref>
In 2010, for ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'', she began creating regular weekly animations (which feature Saunders doing the voices of all the characters).<ref>[http://motherjones.com/authors/zina-saunders/archive Mother Jones: Zina Saunders Archive]</ref>
<!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:Outrezina.jpg|thumb|right|200px]] --> In November 2009, ''Overlooked New York'' was published as a book, collecting more than 60 of the profiles and portraits.
==Awards== Saunders' updated design of the [[Pink Panther (character)|Pink Panther]] character for United Artists brought her an award from ''Print'' and her ''Native Americans'' trading card set of 106 illustrations was chosen Most Creative Trading Card Set by the trade magazine ''Non-Sport Update''.<ref>[http://www.nonsportupdate.com/ "Time Capsule": ''Non-Sport Update'' (December 1996-January 1997)]</ref> She has contributed to numerous trading card sets, including ''[[Wacky Packages]]'', ''[[Magic: The Gathering]]'' and ''[[Goosebumps]]''.
Excerpts from "Art Talks," her series of portraits and interviews with illustrators and art directors, are featured in ''Illo'' magazine. Portraits from that series are in ''American Illustration 26 Annual'' and ''American Illustration 27 Annual''. Five of her portraits were selected for the ''Communication Arts Illustration Annual 2008''. Four pages in ''Graphic: Inside the Sketchbooks of the World's Great Graphic Designers'' by [[Steven Heller (graphic design)|Steven Heller]] and Lita Talarico (Monacelli Press, 2010) demonstrate how her sketches evolve into digital paintings.
Saunders has taught illustration at the [[University of the Arts (Philadelphia)|University of the Arts]] in Philadelphia.
==See also== [[List of illustrators]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Watch== *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100519023415/http://gelconference.com/videos/2009/zina_saunders/#c Zina Saunders at 2009 Gel Conference]
